sub_topic: Finding the period and amplitude of trigonometric functions
message_1: If a trigonometric function is given by f(x) = 3 cos (2x - π/3), find the amplitude and period of the function.
message_2:
The given function is f(x) = 3 cos(2x - π/3).

The general form of a cosine function is A cos(Bx - C), where A is the amplitude, B determines the period, and C is the phase shift.

In our case, A = 3, B = 2, and C = π/3.

The amplitude is the absolute value of A, which is |3| = 3.

The period of the function is given by the formula P = 2π/B. In our case, B = 2, so the period is P = 2π/2 = π.

So, the amplitude of the function is 3, and the period is π.
